title: Dietitian Susie Burrell reveals late-night snacks you should avoid if you want to lose weight
text:
Dietitian Susie Burrell (pictured) has listed the treats you should avoid eating if you want to lose weight

If you're trying to drop a dress size but the waistline just won't budge, your late-night munchies could be holding you back.

Dietitian Susie Burrell, from Sydney, has listed the treats you should avoid eating if you want to lose weight - and the healthier alternatives you can eat if you are feeling peckish after dinner.

Taking to her blog, Susie said indulging on hundreds of extra calories can affect hormones, sleep and weight.

Snacks to avoid

Surprisingly, Susie said dark chocolate can do more harm than good to your body if you are trying to lose weight.

'While we are told that dark chocolate is a better option than milk, the reality is dark chocolate is still high in sugar and fats so best avoided at night if your goal is weight loss,' she said.

Susie said you should avoid things like dark chocolate and even hot chocolate after dinner if you want to lose weight (stock image)

While milk is associated with better sleep quality, Susie suggested avoiding flavoured dairy beverages such as hot chocolate before bedtime.

She said while some hot chocolate brands are advertised as low in calories and less sugar, they often contain sweeteners which can 'prime you to seek out more sweet good and keep snacking'.

Despite being touted as the 'healthier' version of crunchy chips, Susie said a close inspection of the label will reveal ingredients that are relatively high in fat and calories.

She said other treats to avoid are cheese and dips and biscuits.

If you're feeling peckish in front of the television screen, Susie said plain popcorn is a healthy snack option to eat (stock image)

Healthy alternatives

If you're feeling peckish in front of the television screen, Susie said plain popcorn is a healthy snack option to eat.

'A couple of cups of plain popcorn contains less than 10g of carbs and is a fibre rich, low calorie snack option,' she said.

Containing virtually no calories, chopped vegetables, berries and passion fruit are perfect for munching on without feeling any guilt.

If you have a sweet tooth, Susie said low-calorie ice creams are another healthy option to curb your sugar cravings after dinner.

'Not exactly calorie free but a lot lighter than regular ice-cream, the growing range of low calorie treats including Halo Top can contain as few as 100 calories while still offering a sweet hit after your evening meal,' she said.

Susie said you can make low-calorie crackers with Vegemite or light cream cheese with tomato as a healthy snack option.
